                                                                      ï¿½ï¿½ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘— ï¿½+ï¿½ï¿½ğœ‰ğœ‰ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘— + ï¿½ï¿½  ğœ–ğœ–ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½
                                                                                                     ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–
                        ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
                        ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘          ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘™ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ 
                                              ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘  ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘

A consumerâ€™s utility declines in the mortgage rate ğ›¼ğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘– ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘— , with ğ›¼ğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘– measuring the consumer-specific
sensitivity to interest rates.
Borrower ğ‘–ğ‘–â€™s mortgage amount ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘–âˆ— can be smaller than her ideal mortgage size, ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘– . If that is the case,
she suffers a disutility ğ›½ğ›½ğ‘–ğ‘– ğ¼ğ¼(ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘–âˆ— < ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘– ), 10 where the borrower-specific coefficient ğ›½ğ›½ğ‘–ğ‘– measures the extent
of disutility and I is the indicator function. This can occur when the borrowerâ€™s ideal mortgage is a
jumbo ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘– > ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘– , but the borrower chooses a mortgage under the conforming limit ğ¼ğ¼ï¿½ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘–âˆ— < ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘– ï¿½ğ¼ğ¼ï¿½ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘– >
ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘– ï¿½, or when a binding LTV constraint prevents the borrower from obtaining their ideal jumbo
mortgage ğ¼ğ¼ï¿½ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘–âˆ— > ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘– ï¿½ğ¼ğ¼(ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘– > ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
                                        ğ¿ğ¿ğ¿ğ¿ğ¿ğ¿ Ã— ğ‘ƒğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘– ).
Consumers also value mortgages on dimensions other than size and price. For example, conforming
mortgage approval and administrative procedures differ from those of jumbo mortgages. We allow
consumers to have different preferences over these non-rate attributes of conforming relative to jumbo
mortgages, captured by ğ›¾ğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘– . Consumers also value lendersâ€™ convenience and/or service quality.
Intuitively, consumers like to borrow from fintech shadow banks such as Quicken Loans because they
offer a convenient way to interact online. ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘— + ğœ‰ğœ‰ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘— measures convenience differences between
lenders. ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘— is the year-lender type invariant quality difference, 11 and ğœ‰ğœ‰ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘— is a year-lender market-
specific unobservable. ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘— is estimated as a year-lender type fixed effect, and is thus observable by
the researcher, while ğœ‰ğœ‰ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘— is not. Last, borrowersâ€™ preferences over lenders differ idiosyncratically,
which is captured in the i.i.d. T1EV borrower-specific utility shock ğœ–ğœ–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘– . For example, some
borrowers prefer to borrow from JPMorgan Chase over Quicken because they have a bank account
with the former, making it easier to transact.
The ideal mortgage size, interest rate sensitivity, relative preference for a conforming loan, as well as
the cost of departing from the ideal mortgage size are consumer specific. Consumersâ€™ preferences are
drawn from a distribution, where the distribution is a function of income and house prices in a market.
Specifically, let Î’ğ‘–ğ‘– â‰¡ (ğ›¼ğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘– , ğ›½ğ›½ğ‘–ğ‘– , ğ›¾ğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘– , ğ¹ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘– )â€² describe consumer preferences, then:
                                                                       ï¿½ + Î (ğ·ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘– âˆ’ ğ·ğ·
                                                                 Î’ğ‘–ğ‘– = Î’                ï¿½ ) + Î£ğœˆğœˆğ‘–ğ‘–               (D.3)




10
  A consumer will never choose a mortgage which is too large.
11
  Because of large changes in the quality of fintech providers over time, we allow the quality of fintech shadow banks to
evolve over time as well.
